--- title: "Directed Acyclic Graphs" --- This section will introduce an option to graphically represent the relationship between different variables with the help of **directed acylic graphs (DAGs)** # Display parking spot example ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_313a71ff150d3216828dff0c1032e97a'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: As one can see the location influences the number of available spots and sales, while spots also influences the sales # Computing relevant values of data set *costumer_sat.rds* ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_22cbddab3c43221824f14360cc6022bc'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## Regress *satisfaction* on *follow_ups* ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_590c0c41d4f9d1136148d39b3ca287ce'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -12.412 -5.257 1.733 4.506 12.588 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 78.8860 4.2717 18.467 1.04e-10 *** #> follow_ups -3.3093 0.6618 -5.001 0.000243 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.658, Adjusted R-squared: 0.6316 #> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF, p-value: 0.0002427 ``` ::: ::: ## Regress *satisfaction* on *follow_ups* and account for *subscription* ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_a925d9f66d74d8643e21f1f61afaedb4'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -4.3222 -2.1972 0.3167 2.2667 3.9944 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 26.7667 6.6804 4.007 0.00206 ** #> follow_ups 2.1944 0.7795 2.815 0.01682 * #> subscriptionPremium 44.7222 5.6213 7.956 6.88e-06 *** #> subscriptionPremium+ 18.0722 2.1659 8.344 4.37e-06 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.9597, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9487 #> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF, p-value: 5.956e-08 ``` ::: ::: # Compare the coefficients **Satisfaction on follow_ups** m1 = -3.3093 b = 78.886 **Satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription** m1 = 2.1944 m2 = 44.7222 m3 = 18.0722 b = 26.7667 Explanation: As the satisfaction decreases, if the data is not conditioned on subscription, but at the same time increases, if conditioned on subscription you can assume that the subscription has an negative impact on the satisfaction This can have multiple explanations, maybe the product is to expensive or the amount of functions to overwhelming. # Plot data ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_ad652cc06461dc2e0ba6cbf4a13593dd'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: As one can see that if the subscription is accounted for, the satisfaction increases for all subscription tiers if the support does a follow up.
